articles.headline: Getting Out of a 2-Year Cellphone Contract Alive
articles.snippet: It’s not easy to escape a two-year cellphone contract. But it can be done by turning to the innovators on the Internet.
articles.abstract: It’s not easy to escape a two-year cellphone contract. But it can be done by turning to the innovators on the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: The two-year contract. It is the bane of a cellphone owner’s existence, especially one who must have the latest hot phone at a discounted price.

articles.headline: More Finding Work in U.S.
articles.snippet: Employers added 97,000 workers, and the jobless rate ticked down to 4.5 percent from 4.6 percent.
articles.abstract: Employers added 97,000 workers, and the jobless rate ticked down to 4.5 percent from 4.6 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the economy is really slowing as much as some recent statistics suggest, working Americans have so far managed to dodge the bullet.

articles.headline: Google’s Buses Help Its Workers Beat the Rush
articles.snippet: The sheer scale of Google’s new shuttle program for its employees befits the company’s oversize ambitions.
articles.abstract: The sheer scale of Google’s new shuttle program for its employees befits the company’s oversize ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — The perks of working at Google are the envy of Silicon Valley. Unlimited amounts of free chef-prepared food at all times of day. A climbing wall, a volleyball court and two lap pools. On-site car washes, oil changes and haircuts, not to mention free doctor checkups.

articles.headline: Troubles Hit Real Estate at High End
articles.snippet: There are signs that some high-end real estate developers are being hit by a slowdown.
articles.abstract: There are signs that some high-end real estate developers are being hit by a slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until now, deep-pocketed Wall Street tycoons and foreign investors benefiting from a weak dollar seemed to be holding up the luxury real estate market even as the low-end fractured. But there are signs that some high-end real estate developers are also being hit by the slowdown.

articles.headline: Bush and Chávez Spar at Distance Over Latin Visit
articles.snippet: President Bush ended up competing for attention with President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, who called the American visit an act of imperialism, adding, “Gringo, go home!”
articles.abstract: President Bush ended up competing for attention with President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, who called the American visit an act of imperialism, adding, “Gringo, go home!”
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, March 9 — President Bush began the first full day of his weeklong trip to Latin America here on Friday promising job-creating aid but ended up competing for attention with President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, who called the American visit an act of imperialism, adding, “Gringo, go home!”
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Larry Rohter

articles.headline: Some Sectors in Europe Face a Labor Shortage
articles.snippet: The most dynamic, future-oriented industries are having trouble finding qualified employees.
articles.abstract: The most dynamic, future-oriented industries are having trouble finding qualified employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, March 9 — Corinne Margot is reaching deep into her bag of tricks to find new employees.

articles.headline: Revisiting Overstock.com and Utah
articles.snippet: The crusade against “naked short selling” by Patrick M. Byrne, the head of Overstock.com, may be in the midst of a meltdown.
articles.abstract: The crusade against “naked short selling” by Patrick M. Byrne, the head of Overstock.com, may be in the midst of a meltdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the last Monday in February, and another Utah legislative session was coming to a close. A group of lobbyists, legislators and state officials were meeting to hash out the merits of a controversial bill. Among those in the room was our old friend Patrick M. Byrne, the chief executive of Overstock.com, the struggling Internet retailer based in Salt Lake City.

articles.headline: To Have, Hold and Cherish, Until Bedtime
articles.snippet: With many adults having trouble sleeping, more couples are building separate bedrooms, or his-and-her wings.
articles.abstract: With many adults having trouble sleeping, more couples are building separate bedrooms, or his-and-her wings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not since the Victorian age of starched sheets and starchy manners, builders and architects say, have there been so many orders for separate bedrooms. Or separate sleeping nooks. Or his-and-her wings.

articles.headline: Can Your Dog Humanize the Office?
articles.snippet: It had been thought that the patter of paws would go the way of casual Fridays and massages at your desk, but, the dogs, it seems, are here to stay.
articles.abstract: It had been thought that the patter of paws would go the way of casual Fridays and massages at your desk, but, the dogs, it seems, are here to stay.
articles.lead_paragraph: A MEMO was sent last month to the 125 employees of Archer Malmo, a marketing agency in Memphis. Titled “Office Dog Etiquette,” it said in part:

articles.headline: In Romney’s Bid, His Wallet Opens to the Right
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney contributed tens of thousands of dollars to  groups in a position to influence his image on the right.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney contributed tens of thousands of dollars to  groups in a position to influence his image on the right.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 10 — In the months before announcing his bid for the Republican presidential nomination, former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts contributed tens of thousands of dollars of his personal fortune to several conservative groups in a position to influence his image on the right.

articles.headline: Crisis Looms in Market for Mortgages
articles.snippet: For investors who watched the technology bubble burst, the problems in the mortgage securities market have a familiar ring.
articles.abstract: For investors who watched the technology bubble burst, the problems in the mortgage securities market have a familiar ring.
articles.lead_paragraph: On March 1, a Wall Street analyst at Bear Stearns wrote an upbeat report on a company that specializes in making mortgages to cash-poor homebuyers. The company, New Century Financial, had already disclosed that a growing number of borrowers were defaulting, and its stock, at around $15, had lost half its value in three weeks.

articles.headline: Iraq’s Leader Asks for Aid in Curbing Strife
articles.snippet: Envoys for the U.S. and Iran avoided direct talks at a 13-nation  conference as two shells landed near the meeting in Baghdad.
articles.abstract: Envoys for the U.S. and Iran avoided direct talks at a 13-nation  conference as two shells landed near the meeting in Baghdad.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, March 10 — Addressing representatives of 13 nations and three international groups, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki opened a much-anticipated regional conference here with a plea to Iraq’s neighbors to back his efforts to control the violence engulfing the country by refusing to finance attacks or allow foreign fighters to cross their borders.

articles.headline: Weird and Weirder Numbers on Pay Reports
articles.snippet: Shareholders who thought that a quick glance at the summary compensation table would tell them all they needed to know have another thing coming.
articles.abstract: Shareholders who thought that a quick glance at the summary compensation table would tell them all they needed to know have another thing coming.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORING over executive pay filings — packed as they are with all the new details that the Securities and Exchange Commission requires — is turning out to be, no surprise, an exercise in exhaustion. Asking for additional data in the filings, the regulators said, would make them more illuminating.

articles.headline: Edison the Inventor, Edison the Showman
articles.snippet: A new book examines the reality and the myths surrounding the legacy of Thomas Alva Edison.
articles.abstract: A new book examines the reality and the myths surrounding the legacy of Thomas Alva Edison.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was adapted from “The Wizard of Menlo Park: How Thomas Alva Edison Invented the Modern World,” by Randall Stross, a contributor to The New York Times. The book, to be published on Tuesday by Crown Publishers, examines the reality and the myths surrounding the Edison legacy.

articles.headline: Facing Fraud Trial, Conrad Black Flouts the Rules
articles.snippet: Unlike most defendants in corporate malfeasance trials, Mr. Black has chided his accusers and vowed a comeback.
articles.abstract: Unlike most defendants in corporate malfeasance trials, Mr. Black has chided his accusers and vowed a comeback.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO, March 6 — When Conrad M. Black pleaded not guilty to criminal fraud charges in December 2005, a federal court in Chicago granted his request that he be defended by Edward L. Greenspan, one of the most famous criminal defense lawyers in Canada, where he is known by the nickname Fast Eddie.

articles.headline: In New Tactic, Militants Burn Houses in Iraq
articles.snippet: Residents in Diyala Province said the attackers sought to scare people into giving in to extremism or running away.
articles.abstract: Residents in Diyala Province said the attackers sought to scare people into giving in to extremism or running away.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, March 11  Sunni militants burned homes in a mixed city northeast of Baghdad on Saturday and Sunday, forcing dozens of families to flee and raising the specter of a new intimidation tactic in Iraq’s evolving civil war, Iraqi officials and witnesses said.

articles.headline: Voice Lesson: An Outsider in Charge
articles.snippet: Under New Times, The Village Voice, which has always been the home to permanent revolution, continues to flop from one crisis to another.
articles.abstract: Under New Times, The Village Voice, which has always been the home to permanent revolution, continues to flop from one crisis to another.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in 2006, before The Village Voice went into the ditch — before one of its writers was found to have fabricated an article, before its interim editor was fired by a notice that was scrawled on a napkin, before another new editor was hired but then did not take the job, before another one was hired and then fired in six months — I was sitting at the Odeon restaurant in downtown Manhattan with Michael Lacey, one of the partners of New Times, a chain of weekly newspapers that merged with the Voice newspapers in 2005.

articles.headline: Years of Strife and Lost Hope Scar Young Palestinians
articles.snippet: The current generation of young Palestinians, many say, is the most radical, the most accepting of violence and the most despairing.
articles.abstract: The current generation of young Palestinians, many say, is the most radical, the most accepting of violence and the most despairing.
articles.lead_paragraph: NABLUS, West Bank  Their worried parents call them the lost generation of Palestine: its most radical, most accepting of violence and most despairing.

articles.headline: Weak Lead-In Programming Takes a Toll on the News Ratings
articles.snippet: The heated network news competition is still complicated by how much network newscasts squander or build on the programs that precede them.
articles.abstract: The heated network news competition is still complicated by how much network newscasts squander or build on the programs that precede them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, around the time that CBS agreed to pay an estimated $15 million a year to lure Katie Couric away from NBC, it spent several million dollars more in licensing fees to coax another nationally known television personality from the NBC station in New York to the one owned by CBS: Judge Judy.

articles.headline: Lacking Papers, Citizens Are Cut From Medicaid
articles.snippet: A new federal rule intended to keep illegal immigrants from receiving benefits has instead shut out tens of thousands of U.S. citizens.
articles.abstract: A new federal rule intended to keep illegal immigrants from receiving benefits has instead shut out tens of thousands of U.S. citizens.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 11 — A new federal rule intended to keep illegal immigrants from receiving Medicaid has instead shut out tens of thousands of United States citizens who have had difficulty complying with requirements to show birth certificates and other documents proving their citizenship, state officials say.

articles.headline: For War’s Gravely Injured, Challenge to Find Care
articles.snippet: Cases of traumatic brain injury, a signature wound of the Iraq war, are leaving the military health care system scrambling.
articles.abstract: Cases of traumatic brain injury, a signature wound of the Iraq war, are leaving the military health care system scrambling.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Staff Sgt. Jarod Behee was asked to select a paint color for the customized wheelchair that was going to be his future, his young wife seethed. The government, Marissa Behee believed, was giving up on her husband just five months after he took a sniper’s bullet to the head during his second tour of duty in Iraq.
articles.byline: By Deborah Sontag and Lizette Alvarez

articles.headline: Texans Want to Strike Rule on Projecting Retiree Care
articles.snippet: Texas officials argue that a new rule to disclose the size of their health care obligation to retirees  does not apply to their state.
articles.abstract: Texas officials argue that a new rule to disclose the size of their health care obligation to retirees  does not apply to their state.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s 50 states and the largest cities will soon be required to disclose the value of the health care they have promised their retired workers. The prospect of that disclosure, under a new accounting rule, is not a happy one for governments.

articles.headline: Who Owns the Live Music of Days Gone By?
articles.snippet: Radio and TV show archives have become valuable prizes in the desperate search for new content for Web sites and DVDs.
articles.abstract: Radio and TV show archives have become valuable prizes in the desperate search for new content for Web sites and DVDs.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it began in 1973, the “King Biscuit Flower Hour” was very much of its time. Bob Meyrowitz, who ran the show during its heyday, had the idea to start a weekly rock concert radio program as an alternative to chaotic festival shows after a fan was killed at the Rolling Stones performance at Altamont.

articles.headline: Early Primary Rush Upends ’08 Campaign Plans
articles.snippet: Campaigns are reconsidering strategies as they gird for the prospect of a 20-state national Primary Day on Feb. 5.
articles.abstract: Campaigns are reconsidering strategies as they gird for the prospect of a 20-state national Primary Day on Feb. 5.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 9  The trickle of states moving their 2008 presidential primaries to Feb. 5 has turned into an avalanche, forcing all the presidential campaigns to reconsider every aspect of their nominating strategy  where to compete, how to spend money, when to start television advertising  as they gird for the prospect of a 20-state national primary day.
